column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=The following is one particularly well documented incidence of the trafficking of artefacts from Sipan .
#Text=In 1987 , the Moche site of Sipán in Peru was looted and objects taken from that site began to appear on the black market .
#Text=Kirkpatrick interviewed a Peru-based collector named Enrico Poli who claimed that word of the major find reached Lima collecting circles quite soon after the tomb was located .
#Text=After intermediaries in Trujillo sent him artefact samples from Sipán ( which Poli purchased ) , he travelled to Trujillo with $ 40,000 in cash .
#Text=There Poli claims to have met with a former policeman and artefact middleman named Pereda who sold him several objects from the tomb .
#Text=Pereda informed Poli that more artefacts from the site existed , but that the looters were hiding the objects until police investigations had ended .
#Text=While at Pereda ’ s house , Poli claims to have seen crutches belonging to a man named Fred Drew .
#Text=Over the next few days it has been alleged that the Bernal brothers brought various Sipán objects to Pereda ’ s home where they were purchased by either Drew or Poli .
#Text=Fred Drew was a retired American diplomat who had been functioning as a buyer and dealer of Peruvian antiquities for about 20 years before the Sipán looting .
#Text=Drew purchased large portions of the Sipán collection with money provided by a US antiquities dealer named David Swetnam .
#Text=With Drew focusing on the procurement of the Sipán objects , Swetnam devised a way for the pieces to be transported illegally out of Peru .

#Text=Smuggling route through Bolivia and Canada According to the testimony of Michael Kelly ( a member of the smuggling operation , see below ) , Drew and Swetnam had worked together to smuggle antiquities out of Peru in the past .
#Text=Kelly alleged that Drew and Swetnam would normally have agents carry smaller antiquities on direct flights from Lima to the US , sometimes bribing Peruvian customs officers in the process .
#Text=For larger shipments , mud and latex were used to cover genuine antiquities and ‘ Hecho en Bolivia ’ was stamped on the bottom in an attempt to make them look like souvenir items .
#Text=The disguised antiquities would be shipped overland to Bolivia , flown to Vancouver , and then carried into the United States .

#Text=This route worked for at least two shipments of non-Sipán material , but in 1985 a collection of ceramics and textiles sent by Drew and Swetnam was intercepted and authenticated by Canadian authorities .
#Text=In evaluating how to get the Sipán material out of Peru , Swetnam decided that the Bolivia to Canada to the US route was ‘ no longer viable ’ .
#Text=Via London to the USA with a false provenance Drew and Swetnam eventually settled upon the following route which they had previously tested with two smaller shipments of non-Sipán antiquities .
#Text=Drew handed the Sipán objects that he purchased over to Miguel de Osma Berckemeyer , the nephew of a former Peruvian ambassador to the United States .
#Text=Berckemeyer then used family and drug cartel connections to get the objects on cargo planes headed to London .
#Text=At Heathrow airport the objects were picked up by representatives of Fine Arts Services , a bonded warehouse agent , and delivered to Swetnam .
#Text=Once the Sipán material was in the United Kingdom , Swetnam removed the Peruvian newspapers that were used to pack the objects and replaced them with pages from a London paper .
#Text=He packed the objects in a footlocker and covered them with a raincoat belonging to the father of a man named Michael Kelly .

#Text=Kelly , a British ex-pat who was the director of a small California-based company called Art Collections Conservation Network , was to receive the footlocker full of Sipán objects when they arrived in the USA .
#Text=Kelly ’ s recently deceased father was a British subject who had travelled in South America in the 1920s .
#Text=If asked , Kelly was to claim that the Sipán objects had been collected by his father during his travels , providing a plausible false provenance for the shipment .
#Text=Letters bearing this story were also sent to potential buyers within the US .
#Text=Both Swetnam and Kelly were present to pick up the shipment of Sipán material at Los Angeles International Airport .
#Text=The shipment was labelled ‘ personal effects ’ and Swetnam and Kelly paid no duty on it .
#Text=Customs agents did not look inside the footlocker .
#Text=The men transported the Sipán objects to the home of Benjamin Bishop Johnson , a collector , dealer , and authenticator of Pre-Conquest antiquities .
#Text=Johnson authenticated the shipment and purchased at least some of the items .

#Text=Kelly testifies to US Customs resulting in raids On 18 September 1987 , Kelly contacted United States Customs agent Gaston Wallace and indicated that he had played a role in the trafficking of a large shipment of undocumented antiquities into the United States .
#Text=Kelly claimed that he got involved with Swetnam because his business was near bankruptcy .
#Text=When his father died in 1986 , Kelly was unable to pay for airfare back to the UK for the funeral .
#Text=Swetnam offered to pay for Kelly ’ s plane tickets if Kelly agreed to collect illegally exported Peruvian objects in London and provide a false provenance based on his father ’ s death .

#Text=Although Kelly admitted that he knew he was joining a smuggling operation , he stated that he did not know how deeply he was getting involved until he saw the undocumented antiquities from the Sipán shipment .
#Text=He agreed to become a confidential informant and a federal investigation was initiated .
#Text=On 30 March 1988 US Customs conducted a series of raids on targets identified through secret recordings made by Kelly .
#Text=Among the properties raided was the home of retired Crocker Bank executive Charles Craig in Santa Barbara .
#Text=Papers found in Craig ’ s home led investigators to the Santa Barbara Museum of Art .
#Text=There investigators found twenty objects that had been in Swetnam ’ s inventory and another seven that Kelly identified as having been smuggled into the US by himself and Swetnam .
#Text=Several of these objects thought to be from Sipán were slated to be put on display at the museum two days after the raid in an exhibit entitled ‘ Diverse Directions : A Collector ’ s Choice ’ .
#Text=Thus within four months of being removed from the ground , objects from Sipán would have been placed on view in a US museum .
#Text=Swetnam convicted In 1989 David Swetnam and his wife Jacqueline were charged with ten counts of conspiracy , customs violations , and other smuggling charges .
#Text=Swetnam agreed to plead guilty to three counts of receiving and causing the importation of nine artefacts in an agreement that involved the charges against his wife being dropped .
#Text=On 26 June 1989 Swetnam was sentenced to six months in prison .
#Text=He served four months of the sentence .
